current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To establish the Maritime Washington National Heritage Area in the State of Washington, and for
			 other purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Maritime Washington National Heritage Area Act

text.#text: The term
The term
The term
The purposes of this Act are—

to encourage and strengthen partnerships and collaboration among maritime interests for the purpose
			 of economic development and heritage tourism;

to recognize that waterfronts are both a foundational part of the heritage of the State and dynamic
			 places that are constantly adapting to new opportunities and challenges;

to recognize, interpret, and conserve the diverse and abundant nationally significant
			 maritime-related objects, sites, structures, places, events, and
			 activities that collectively form a distinctive landscape in  ports and
			 coastal communities located in the western part of the State;

to recognize and interpret the impact of that nationally important maritime landscape on Native
			 American and European-American heritage;

to preserve landscapes, communities, traditions, historic sites, and natural features in the
			 Heritage Area associated with that maritime history;

to promote heritage, cultural, and recreational tourism, and to develop educational, interpretive,
			 recreational, and cultural programs through partnerships for the benefit
			 of visitors and the general public; and

to provide appropriate linkages between Federal, State, and local historic sites, and communities,
			 governments, businesses, organizations, and individuals that stimulate
			 appropriate and compatible economic vitality within the Heritage Area,
			 without modifying the authority of any State, tribal, or local government
			 to regulate land use, public land policy, or private activity.

There is established the Maritime Washington National Heritage Area in the counties of Whatcom,
			 Skagit, Snohomish, San Juan, Island, King, Pierce, Thurston, Mason,
			 Kitsap, Jefferson, Clallam, and Grays Harbor in the State.
The Heritage Area shall consist of Federal, State, local, and tribal land that—

allows public access;
			 and
is at least partly located within the area that is

fraction.#tail:
-mile landward of the
			 shoreline, as generally depicted on the map.

The map shall be on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the

The local coordinating entity for the Heritage Area shall be the Pacific Northwest Maritime
			 Heritage Advisory Council, operating under the Washington Trust for
			 Historic Preservation.

header.#text: Duties and authorities of local coordinating entity

text.#text: To support the purposes of the Heritage Area, the local coordinating entity shall—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, a management plan for the
			 Heritage Area;
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Maritime Washington National Heritage Area Act/s:6

text.#text: prepare and submit to the

assist willing partners, such as units of State, local, and tribal government, regional planning
			 organizations, and private organizations, in implementing the approved
			 management plan by—

advocating for and carrying out programs and projects that recognize and protect important resource
			 values within the Heritage Area;
promoting, developing, and maintaining interpretive exhibits and programs within the Heritage Area;
promoting or developing recreational and educational opportunities in the Heritage Area;

increasing public awareness of, and appreciation for, natural, historic, scenic, recreational, and
			 cultural resources of the Heritage Area;

ensuring that signs identifying points of public access and sites of interest are posted throughout
			 the Heritage Area; and

promoting a wide range of partnerships among governments, businesses, organizations, and
			 individuals to support the purposes of the Heritage Area;

take into consideration the interests of diverse units of government, businesses, organizations,
			 and individuals
			 in the Heritage Area in the preparation and implementation of the
			 management plan;

ensure an open and transparent process for the development and implementation of the management
			 plan by holding regular public meetings;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
an annual report for each fiscal year during which the local coordinating
			 entity receives Federal funds under this Act that describes, with respect
			 to the reporting period—

the goals and accomplishments of the local coordinating entity;
the expenses and income of the local coordinating entity;
the amounts and sources of matching funds;
the amounts leveraged with Federal funds and sources of the leveraged funds;
grants made to any other entities; and
critical components for sustainability of the Heritage Area;

in all agreements authorizing expenditures of Federal funds by other organizations, ensure that the
			 receiving organizations make available for audit all records and other
			 information pertaining to the expenditure of the funds; and

encourage and strengthen partnerships and collaboration among maritime interests by appropriate
			 means for economic development and heritage tourism, consistent with the
			 purposes of the Heritage Area.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:

The local coordinating entity may not use Federal funds received under this Act to acquire any
			 interest in real property.

text.#text:
Not later than 3 years after the date on which funds are made available to develop the management
			 plan, the local coordinating entity shall submit to the
The management plan for the Heritage Area shall—

describe comprehensive policies, goals, strategies, and recommendations for the conservation,
			 funding, management, interpretation, and development of the Heritage Area;

take into consideration existing State and local plans in the development and implementation of the
			 management plan;

specify existing and potential sources of funding or economic development strategies to conserve,
			 manage, and develop the Heritage Area;

recommend policies and strategies for resource management, including the development of
			 intergovernmental and interagency agreements, to protect the natural,
			 historic, cultural, educational, scenic, and recreational resources of the
			 Heritage Area;
describe a program for implementation of the management plan, including—
performance goals;
an approximate timeline for implementation;
specific commitments for implementation; and
how the plan will be evaluated and updated;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:

			 support the purposes of this Act;

provides adequate assurances that the local coordinating entity has the partnerships and financial
			 and other resources necessary to implement the management plan for the
			 Heritage Area; and

describes goals and recommendations for sustainability of the coordinating entity through the
			 effective period of this Act.

text.#text: the
On completion of a report under this paragraph, the

Nothing in this Act affects the authority of any Federal agency to provide technical or financial
			 assistance under any other law (including regulations).

To the maximum extent practicable, the head of any Federal agency planning to conduct activities
			 that may have an impact on the Heritage Area is encouraged to consult and
			 coordinate the activities with the
Nothing in this Act—

modifies, alters, or amends any laws (including regulations) authorizing a Federal agency to manage
			 land under the jurisdiction of the Federal agency;

limits the discretion of a Federal land manager to implement an approved land use plan within the
			 boundaries of the Heritage Area; or

modifies, alters, or amends any authorized use of Federal land under the jurisdiction of a Federal
			 agency.
Nothing in this Act—
requires any property owner—

to permit public access (including Federal, State, tribal, or local government access) to the
			 property; or

to modify any provision of Federal, State, tribal, or local law with regard to public access or use
			 of private land;

alters any duly adopted land use regulation, approved land-use plan, or any other regulatory
			 authority of any Federal, State, or local agency, or tribal government;
conveys any land use or other regulatory authority to the local coordinating entity;
authorizes or implies the reservation or appropriation of water or water rights;

diminishes the authority of the State to manage fish and wildlife, including the regulation of
			 fishing and hunting within the Heritage Area; or

creates any liability, or affects any liability under any other law, of any private property owner
			 with respect to any individual injured on the private property.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}fund.#tail:

			 $500,000 shall be made available for any fiscal year.
